Hey Shippiddge! If you are reading this, I would like to tell you that I never understood why this episode is all about Squirtle. The next will be peakğŸ—».
Need more
Decided to revisit my favorite fan-animation in hopeful preparation for episode 11 and I found myself thinking a lot about Charmander and Squirtle's relationship. It's kind of tragic how they couldn't be proper friends because of their shortcomings; in their own ways, each failed to realize in time what was truly important. I feel like if they'd both matured sooner they would've found what they needed in each other; instead Charmander went on an aimless destructive crusade and Squirtle relinquished his free will to avoid facing the reality and the weight of his past actions. I love watching lighthearted projects grow into increasingly ambitious shows of the creator's true artistic potential.
I have a confession to make. I was an avid watcher of Starter Squad back when it was premiering. I'd waited the weeks and months and years between episodes, always satisfied when a new one came out, always patiently waiting for the next, as I was aware animation takes forever and is art. When it'd finally come time for episode 10, even though I'd been waiting for it for a long time, I didn't watch it right away. I was going through some things at the time, so I added it to my watch later and told myself that I'd watch it when I had the time. Truth be told, I didn't want to watch it, because I didn't want it to end. For years those three pokemon grew with me, and I looked forward to seeing the continuation of their little adventures, they even felt something like old friends. I think that on some level, they stand as a sort of symbol of that time in my life, those days I wish I had back, and perhaps like I've been holding onto this video, I've also been holding onto my past. Well, here I am, old friends. I'm ready for the next adventure.

23:17 Ok, hot take, like , EXTREMELY hot take, but Squirtle, I can think of MANY situations where that train of logic might not fly. Like, what if someone is being threatened with the loss of their life? Or the life of a loved one? Or all of their friends and family? Or what if the person who's telling them to do something is stronger than them? What can they do? Fight back? The controller is stronger than them, so they'd just get beaten to a pulp, or worse, killed! Heck, since Snow is an "emmesarey of the gods," it's plausible that the latter situation is his situation. You say he always had a choice, but if the supposed god really is an omnipotent being, or simply just a miriad of times stronger than him, then he would have chosen death, as the "god" would probably just kill him, and then do all of the killing they wanted Snow to do themself, or just pawn it off to some other victim who isn't strong enough to fight back. I get that it ties into Squirtle's arc about taking accountability for his actions, but there was an opportunity for him to fight back against Caterpie. He could've blasted them with water the way he did to Charmander to stop them from killing him. And then he could've freed Bulbasaur and together the 3 of them could've fought to escape the Caterpie's hideout. Meanwhile with Snow, I HEAVILY doubt he could've done ANYTHING to the supposed God which very well COULD BE a god considering that Arceus exists in PokÃ©mon. So comparing his situation to Squirtle's feels a tad victim blamey.

The Cerebus Effect is a trope that is defined by a work starting out in a comedy-adjacent tone or genre that either quickly or by a not so slow burn turns into a drama with a more serious tone, the trope-namer being Cerebus, a comic book series that in the beginning was comedic and episodic, but turned more gritty and dark over time.

"Your heisenberg"
So Charmander started off as selfish, he still was, but when Squirtle tried to teach him that force isn't what makes a leader, he tried to use empathy and redeem himself by trying to save Squirtle. Squirtle was always trying to follow the rules unless someone he viewed as an authority figure tried to make him break them, but by doing what he's told he loses the one guy who actually viewed him as an equal and gave up his free will to not feel guilty for what Caterpie made him do. Now that he looks back on his past and tries to hold himself accountable, he sort of embodied Charmanders initial desire to evolve and his belief that the rules Squirtle followed were not worth it when following them caused him suffering.

I see a lot of parallels between this series and Charlie the Unicorn. Both animated comedy series. Btw altho Charmander might come back, I really like the fact that he is gone Not in a cynical way, but like story-writing. Stories like these have gotten really old It's always the same thing where it all works out, rince and repeat. So what you did with it is simply just more interesting Also, I'm considering this to b Season 2 lol  It's also really satisfying to see Squirtle suffer the consequences with those flashbacks of what happened w the side he chose Still not done w this episode but so far he still doesn't know that Charmander was trying to rescue him the whole time I supposed it's satisfying cuz it's also my own anger of watching Charmander go through all of that just to be brutally betrayed and misunderstood  Again, so much better story-writing than the same old "power of friendship" where it all works out rainbows n sunshine So now when that does happen, it'll definitely be earned

The story is awesome, but this is a complete reboot. Either I feel really bad for turtwig and chimchar for their lack of personality and relevance, or the story is basically over since every other protagonist is out of the game. I wondered why abomasnow speaks exactly like mewtwo, but I guess this fact was just not useful to the plot. And what about the "find me in Cerulean cave don't forget CE-RU-LE-AN-CA-VE" bollocks? Last option is Dirtle getting there, but since Mewtwo kept fighting, it didn't work, and the reboot will just leave too many unturned stones.  Since a reboot is a possibility, the "2 more episodes" is just a soft limitation. If stones are kept unturned, the story doesn't ever have to actually end. I guess that means it's a perfect representation of the PokÃ©mon world, then. That's all the anime has been about since Ash delivered the GS ball, after all.

sooo i just noticed the orange "hat" on caterpie...  So not only was the evolution notion a play on metaphor that Squirtle would never grow pass that stage of his life since his mistake, but he only suffered an exaggerated personality disorder of submissive behaviors due to that mistake. He actually refuses to evolve by choice because he hurt Charmander within an inch of his life believing that he "just wanted to evolve" (obviously not thinking through right away about how Charmander risked his life going down there to save him, Squirtle being too blinded by deaths to see that his friend actually cared for him) and it was originally his friend's plan that they all do evolve.   Even Whiskers saw it in his eyes that killing was no longer a problem for him since that's all Charmander did and his actions and choice led to the combination of his trainer, wearing his friend's severed head, telling him what to do all the time as he's already the submissive type; he blamed himself the whole time... I've gotta say Wonderful job with the voice acting and animation but, Jeez man it's just not a good direction for the plot I'ma break this down into different sections â€¢ The untimely death of Charmander â€¢ The fridging of Bulbasaur â€¢ The destruction of the missingno plot â€¢ The time skip & new characters â€¢ The solution Yep I'm... Really posting an essay on a comedy/light lore Pokemon series.  The Untimely death of charmander  Charmander started the series as a pretty standard arrogant douchebag, but his character development was done wonderfully. Charmander's character development finally paid off when he stormed the Caterpie hideout to save Squirtle, and throughout this entire raid he tried his best to show mercy to the Caterpie whomst he would have slaughtered if the incident had happened earlier. He gives EVERYONE a chance to escape, but the Caterpie are so damn stubborn so he ends up needing to fight anyway. Now what happens to Charmander after showing empathy, compassion, and mercy... Squirtle who was IN EARSHOT when Charmander said "give Squirtle back and I won't hurt anyone" tortures Charmander with water gun... And then he gets decapitated. Then his death is played off as a joke in this episode, because funny hat.   The fridging of Bulbasaur  Bulbasaur was a great, and genuinely funny character. He doesn't appear once in this episode not even a flashback is given to him. We are simply told that he was enslaved, and used as a food source for the rest of his life. Then Squirtle gives a really upsetting line "He had the happiest ending of all of us..." WHAT!?! That is quite possibly the WORST ending for an actually likable character.   The destruction of the missingno plot  The missingno plot was actually interesting because it was an event caused by the characters, and it was an intriguing and creepy mystery. Missingno had something as strong as Mewtwo angry and terrified. It is my suspicion that it was originally intended for Squirtle to be rescued, and the missingno plot to continue, but nope apparently we needed to essentially kill off two main characters flee the country and skip forward 10 years. This episode has ONE mention of missingno in one of Squirtles flashbacks (I'm pretty sure)   The time skip & new characters  I'm pretty sure the majority of people just groaned when they saw the 10 years later, because it's the last thing you want to see after a cliffhanger. The feeling of dread only intensified once chimchar appeared on screen. Here's a hint DO NOT MAKE YOUR AUDIENCE UNSATIFIED JUST FOR SHOCK VALUE this shit royally screws the story. I doubt anyone cares about chimchar when they get like 3 minutes of screen time and immediately die, and all that on top of just being a watered down Charmander just made me miss the twenty minutes before watching this episode even more. Seriously the two new starters get barely any screentime, and zero memorable lines. The SNOVER are more entertaining than any other character introduced here.   The solution  Really the only solution here is to rhetcon the episode, and it seems like that is the direction this is going. We know that Arceus and some other pokemon gods live on top of the mountain, and most likely dialga will be there. This means that time travel is possible, and will most likely put Squirtle back into his body before he was level 99 and a Wartortle with the experience he gained being mental experience.

Especially since Mewtwo told them to meet him in Cerulean Cave and we NEED to know what that was all about.

First off, we have a 10 year time skip for some reason, and ChimChar decides to leave and we barely get to know him. Then, Turtwig leaves, meaning Squirtle is the only one left. We got little to no character development whatsoever, which I donâ€™t know about you, but that was just a waste of time. I enjoyed this series, but personally, I'm not a fan of this episode. Felt like it was trying too hard to be a deep, complex story. Like there was no mention of any gods before this episode. I don't even think anyone said "oh my God" so it just felt super random.  And Chimchar's death was also weird. Were we supposed to feel sad? The guy was alive for less than 5 minutes on screen so there was no connection made with the viewer whatsoever. Not to mention that he was a total prick. At least Charmander had some redeemable qualities (leadership, free thinker, funny). Chimchar just opened up by attacking some random Bidoof but needing to get saved.   Overall, I still think the series has the potential to end well, but this was disappointing.

How to make a parody series. - Start off with comedic jokes as the main focus in the series -Give the main cast defining character traits. -Deliver an emotional turning point in the middle of the series. -Have a tone shift where the series becomes more story focused while still placing jokes in the right place.

a fun little Easter Egg: if you watch this with subtitles, whenever the Snovers talk about â€œSnow in the wayâ€ the S is capitalized, meaning that they were always talking about someone and not the snow itself. When Squirtle talks about snow, the S is lowercase. That was pretty clever.

And seeing Squirtle's growth (And downfall considering how many people he killed and is now going to ask gods to revive his friends) perfectly keeps Charmander's spirit but with a twist. How to Make Classic Cheesecake  You only need a few basic staple ingredients for this cheesecake recipe.  Block cream cheese: Four 8-ounce blocks of full-fat cream cheese are the base of this cheesecake. Thatâ€™s 2 pounds. Make sure youâ€™re buying the blocks of cream cheese and not cream cheese spread. Thereâ€™s no diets allowed in cheesecake, so donâ€™t pick up the reduced fat variety! Sugar: 1 cup.  Not that much considering how many mouths you can feed with this dessert. Over-sweetened cheesecake is hardly cheesecake anymore. Using only 1 cup of sugar gives this cheesecake the opportunity to balance tangy and sweet, just as classic cheesecake should taste. Sour cream: 1 cup. I recently tested a cheesecake recipe with 1 cup of heavy cream instead, but ended up sticking with my original (which can be found here with blueberry swirls!). I was curious about the heavy cream addition and figured it would yield a softer cheesecake bite. The cheesecake was soft, but lacked the stability and richness I wanted. It was almost too creamy. Sour cream is most definitely the right choice. A little flavor: 1 teaspoon of pure vanilla extract and 2 of lemon juice. The lemon juice brightens up the cheesecakeâ€™s overall flavor and vanilla is always a good idea.  Eggs: 3 eggs are the final ingredient. Youâ€™ll beat the eggs in last, one at a time, until they are *just* incorporated. Do not overmix the batter once the eggs are added. This will whip air into the cheesecake batter, resulting in cheesecake cracking and deflating. And as always, make sure all of the cheesecake batter ingredients are at room temperature so the batter remains smooth, even, and combines quickly. Beating cold ingredients together will result in a chunky over-beaten cheesecake batter, hardly the way we want to start!

Can't believe this slip by my notifications. I love the character development of Squirtle. Charmander, Caterpie and Chimchar all had one thing in common. They let their anger and thirst for power cloud their judgment. Caterpie may have gotten his revenge on Charmander but he learned nothing from it.  Squirtle was the voice of reason but he kept choosing to follow. Then he ultimately became a mindless follower to Caterpie because he wanted stability but Caterpie was no better than Charmander. Squirtle finally realized that mindlessly following is always a recipe for disaster. Charmander got what was coming to him. Squirtle got his redemption. Such great writing.

Well dang I'm happy and upset about this episode I really thought Charmander was going to live but on the other hand I loved this story that Squirtle/Wartortle went through.
I discovered and watched this entire series yesterday and so far I love how this many year long project has developed. I think how this story revolves around the pokemon and not their trainers and their inability to grasp their own nature is a very original take on this franchise. The fact that they are able to use pokeballs to enslave each other, and that they have conflicting feelings towards the turn taking in battle (because that's what the humans tell them to do), as well as some of them aspiring to live alongside the humans while others just want to stay away from them, makes their bonds feel a lot more human. What struck me was how Butterfree's incapability to use any of her captures to great effect, since she is not a human, ended up costing her her own life and the escape of Charmander. Though she, alongside many other Pokemon, could understand the mechanism of the pokeballs, she failed to train the pokemon properly because she probably didn't have any badges, as seen with Golem and Geodude.  I mourn the death of Charmander, I carry the burden that Squirtle has, and I kind of resent Bulbasaur's complete obliviousness to this world, who is still probably alive somewhere. Squirle never erased the memory of Charmander, to the point that he always called the much younger Chimchar, "Char". What we can all hope is that Blue Shell Man Guy can make piece with himself in his new form and find the strength to redeem Pokemanity. I don't expect him to be on the bad side of Mewtwo. I think the gods must be Palkia and Dialga or something like that. Maybe he will resuscitate Chimchar. Even though I started watching this series yesterday it really feels like an epic tale.
Yes

Wartortle going shaggy 100% mode agaisnt snow lol
Idea on what happens next:  On top of snow way is a place where legendary pokemon like Arceus Dialga and Palkia live. Wartortle learns of some kind of impending doom up here, but he is too weak to do anything about it alone. He returns back to Kanto to warn the last friends he has about what is going to happen. He learns that after Caterpie released Squirtle, it begged Nidorina to help it recover the forest at any cost. They reunite with Bulbasaur and Sandslash with the help of Mewtwo and they recover the forest. When Wartortle returns to see Venasaur and Nidoqueen he finds out he is the only one among them who still isn't fully evolved. Wartortle then learns he can go to Pokemon Tower to talk to the spirit of Charmander. Wartortle meets Charmander who is now a ghastly/haunter/gengar. Charmander immediately lashes out when he sees Wartortle about how he went to the ends of the Earth for him but he just watched him die. Wartortle takes it, and the two end up realizing why eachother acted the way he did. Wartortle is shocked to learn how much Charmander has grown to appreciate him, and Charmander realizes how his destructive actions turned Squirtle away. After the two make ammends, the impending doom becomes impending and they have to deal with it. Wartortle evolves into Blastoise in the final battle and sacrifices himself to save the day. After dealing with it everyone learns a lesson about respecting eachother and taking responsibility for your own actions and how people can change and everyone lives happily ever after. Blastoise and Charmander live happily in Pokemon Tower and Charmander is proud of how strong Blastoise has gotten.

This feels like a spinoff series moreso than a fluid continuation of the story. I feel like Charmander's death was just for shock value and nothing else. Why kill him before his arc was complete? That just invalidates all the growth he had up until that point. And why don't we get to see Squirtle's arc at all outside of flashbacks? It just feels like the story was skipped over and left unfinished, and now we're just moving on.
This is fantastic writing. Shifting the protagonist makes it feel so unpredictable. The fact that Charmander is gone for good means that nothing is protected by plot armor anymore. And thats how you keep everyone on their toes !!

I like how this episode gives greater meaning to the personality quirks of Charmander and Squirtle throughout the series, Charmander represented choice and free will in the series and even states to Catterpie that trainers and pokemon should stand next to each other, whereas Squirtle has represented freedom of consequence such as wanting to follow some sort of code of battle because he feels like he just should even when his friends are being beaten up and proven even further here where we see his willingness to listen to Catterpie's messed up orders, him snapping at the end was him finally accepting the consequences of his actions, it's why he gets mad at Snow for trying to hoist Chimchar's death on the gods.

This is a very drastic change of tone, and I'm not sure how I feel about it. It was there somewhat in the last episode, but it still somehow juggled those while still feeling as fun and being as entertaining as the original episodes.  My sister and I have been waiting for this for a very long time and by the end we didn't feel much. The humor didn't feel as well crafted as before, and was kinda sidelined for the more serious stuff. Which would have been fine I suppose, but somehow the way they did it was off-putting and felt like a hard zig for the sake of it. It's not like it's poorly written altogether or anything, but this is a very strange departure and there wasn't much to soften the blow.

It is insane how powerful of a message this has. This basically relates with soldiers and politicians out there, people usually blame the big leaders for whatever war or bad events happen but it is the actions of the people that follow said leader who should be at fault. Some would argue that they are just following orders or that it is part of their job to be a yes man, but at the end of the day it is THEIR choices and THEIR fault for what happens out there. Not saying that this is how every soldier or politician is like but this episode showcases a cautionary tale of what happens when you become mindlessly obedient with the wrong people and it is amazing. And let's not forget.....we're talking about a fan-made pokemon animated episode here.

Oh my gosh
Pokemon video should not elicit a in depth response from me but damn was this good.   Despite it being sad, Charmander's death was deserved. We all laughed at him killing and beheading caterpie but no one is laughing now. That's because Charmander's rampant murder spree has caught up with him. The few moments he starts to "get it" are obscured by past mistakes and new ones. By the time he learned his lesson he was beaten within an inch of his life and then betrayed and finally killed. All because he was pissed that he wasn't picked and thought he could kill with no oversight or discretion on his own. As good as his principles were. He reveled in crushing the weak, bullying, and terrorizing.  Then here's Squirtle who was slavishly devoted to maintaining the status quo. So much so that he stood there and let his friend get killed and also went on to kill others all while under the veil of, "You made me do this".

WOOOOOOOO
Well this was something. Firstly I want to say congrats on finally getting the episode done, you've clearly put a lot o effort into it.  I have a bit of criticism though. Throughout the series we've been following the adventures of Squirtle, Charmander and Bulbasaur. Seeing how they try to get stronger, growing closer as friends and helping each other. Sure they butted heads but no friendship is perfect. Also the humor was top notch in many of the episodes. Here though..... it feels like a different story all together .  Charmander was kinda the main focus of the series and we saw how he developed to value his friends and learned empathy. He was busy having character development. But..... now he's just dead...... like.... why? That means all his character development was wasted and served no real purpose in the grand scheme of things. That's severely disappointing.  Like I said this doesn't feel like the same series. The premise and theme of it changed completely. What once was a fun series of misadventures with the starters, is now a post war story. I'm sorry I'm not onboard with that.  I'm still gonna see what you have planned for this series but, honestly I'm very hesitant. Not because of how dark this series has become, but because of the story structure and change of the overall premise .   I still wish you luck though.

Abomasnow is at a minimum level 40 (unless he straight up breaks the rules of level evolving), but couldn't do much to OHKO the level 98 Squirtle even using his most effective attack, Wood Hammer (which I'm assuming he was using) and could only take Wartortle faster than him around level 60 - less if he actually Mega evolved or was a Dynamax. First, I believed you would deliver for the tenth time in a row and I placed my faith very wisely. Second, I felt emotional when my suspicions of Charmander being dead were confirmed. Third, Caterpie always seemed like the real villain of the series to me. Fourth, the music kicks ass and Castlevania III came to mind during the fight between Wartortle and Abomasnow. Fifth, Wartortle is easily and undeniably my favourite out of Squirtle, Wartortle and Blastoise so I was extremely happy to see Blue Shell Man Guy evolve. Sixth, the animation is better than it has ever been during the eight years that the show has been running for so far. Seventh, the storytelling is extremely excellent and I am always excited to see what comes next. Eighth, I shall sign up on Patreon to support you and your squad as best I can here in Canada. Ninth, my favourite PokÃ©mon is Delphox. And tenth, most importantly: Thank you for entertaining me with a series that I have followed passionately since it first began. I was thirteen going on fourteen back when it began and I have only Loved the series more and more with every rewatch. Thank you for everything so far, Pierce. I am looking forward to all that is to come, along with the countless rewatches that me and my wife will witness.

The giant was called "Adasmastor" and he looked like how we stereotypically think what Zeus looked like (white hair and beard) but completely naked. I wonder what would have happened if Charmander won and succeed in getting Squirtle
I think I've figured out what Squirtle's fear is, at least my version anyway: It was mix of blind Faith and breaking the rules.  Let me explain it this way: in the begining, Squirtle was the one trying to put common sense into Charmander with logic and basic facts. It becomes a recurring issue between them. He tries to argue that 'cheating' would only lead to a worse out come, that they'll be better off with an actual trainer.   The thing is, Charmander wasn't wrong either here. As much as followed his story, seen him act in a monsterous way, it did become clear how complacent Pokemon became once captured. As soon as their trainers fled in fear and left behind their own Pokemon, said mon grows scared and begs for mercy.  It in a way is a fight between two different extremes between Squirtle and Charmander. Yet, in the end it ended in concequence. Because Charmander sauht to evolve quickly, he decided to kill as a way to speed it up and saw it as 'the actual fighting way,' which lead to a war being started after killing the wrong Pokemon. If Charmander had obeyed the rules, this probably wouldn't have happened. Squirtle on the other hand, was also in on the conflict. He was complacent on everything, even while it seemed he made his own choices, because he followed most orders given to him.  Squirtle obeyed Charmander's only reluctantly, trying to convince him to not kill anymore, only really stopping when the line was about to be crossed or when it came down to the rules. Then he obeyed the Catierpie leader too in some aspects. Before Charmander was killed, he was reluctant but obedient to them, then stood by when ordered to and watched Charmander die. Then after that basically broke and followed orders blindly, not even caring anymore.  In the end, the conflict went apocalyptic. No one won, and Squirtle was left standing alone in the remains. The weight of what he let himself do and what his blind Faith had done.   This is what I could peice together, but maybe someone could add to it or share their own ideas? I only could peice what I could.

[If you're looking at the comments before finishing, spoilers, also speculation]  Well, stuff got extra messed up really quickly; Sad to see the starter quad end in such a bleak note, specially with how charmander was my favourite character, but total respect for the bold move. It's interesting see how squirtle both grew up, but at the same time ended up getting some of charmander's personality in this obsession of trying to relive the past (forced friendship, beating up random bidoof instead of his classic "let's solve this peacefully").  With how "damn you, sad time" the story has been now, I don't think we'll get an actual good good ending of squirtle (whatever) going back to save charmander, but the chance to say a last goodbye, quenching some of his regret, saving and saying sorry to chimchar instead, and then finally moving on, maybe even helping mewtwo in tying up the missingno. thing from a long time ago. (also, what happened with piplup? did squirtle do something to piplup so he could be with the gen4 starters!?)  Now it's time to wait another 3,000 years for the next episode yay (smile cry emoji)

Episode 11 here i come.
Feels weird that Charmander's 8 year long character arc kinda got brushed aside in a "10 years later" soft reboot where the development is all  of a sudden given to Squirtle honestly.  I don't mind the lack of a happy ending but it kinda feels like script whiplash suddenly being in Sinnoh and only seeing the last ten years of Squirtle's life in a couple quick flashbacks. Comes off like some massive pills to swallow were more or less brushed off given the pacing. I'm still invested, and for all I know maybe Charmander's story ISN'T over, but if it is I'd have preferred something less abrupt, something to milk out the emotions for the rash protagonist we've followed for so long.   Squirtle himself is handled well (though him going saiyan as a Wartortle is rather silly, however it could be explained as him holding off his evolution for way too long) and it is interesting to see him completely broken and robotic, definitely not an "I told you so" he wanted to be right about. Seeing the foil character take the spotlight so suddenly is weird but it's handled well at least

Wait a minute. It's been so long. I have to go over the first nine episodes again
2 more episodes
That was.... Dissapointing. Killing off the main character just as he reaches the climax of his arc, and then continuing on with a new focus is a bold move; and I really don't think it worked out here. Changing the tone of the entire series so drastically is another large risk, and the change wasn't fluid enough to make it work. Maybe my opinion will change when the rest of the series is out, but right now I'm not exactly on the edge of my seat.  I don't care about Char or Turtwig. The long standing base motivation of the story switched without much (if any) closure. It's as if the previous 9 episodes meant nothing. Like we're starting on a whole new series, or rather a sequal, without ever finishing the first.  The flashbacks Squirtle has are the most interesting. It's heart-wrenching to watch our new protagonist's descent into servitude; his soulless trudge through a war he allowed to happen due to his own lack of action, and failure to protect his friend, and his apathethy towards his sudden freedom. I hope to see more of that in the next episodes,  Squirtle's story arc in this single episode is vast, and the story itself was fantastic. Having him holding an everstone to avoid evolving without charmander (I'm assuming that's the motivation behind it,) and then removing it to fight for the freedom his friend had always longed for, was a beautiful use of symbolisym. Knowing he was trying to replace his old buddies by recruiting children is a good touch as well, but there's one massive problem. It all happens too fast. We had so little chance to get involved with the brand new plotline, that the climactic removal of the stone didn't leave as big of an impression as it could have. We (the watchers) weren't given enough time to feel squirtle's building rage and sadness, so when he released it in what was an epic battle and monolog, we couldn't feel it as strongly as we could have if we'd been given the proper buid up.  Time to wait another 3 years to see where this train rides.

When I watched this I gotta say I am honestly a bit weirded out that charamander died. At first I though he was the main character of the series since he had a ton of screen time and it was setting the series up for a whole arc for charmander to learn what it is to really be a leader and learn and work with his friend's. Squrtle seemed more like a mentor character and the voice of reason of the group tbh, but then he dies making him feel more like an unimportant set-up character, which made me feel bad for charmander since at the end of ep 9 he finally got to squrtle, it seemed like after he survived the caterpy he would have to continued to grow as a character and become a better person finally realizing his mistakes and change for the better, which I don't mean to criticize. ( Since y'all spent so long and put so much effort into this so alone and the series in general, congrats btw. ) It feels like char's whole arc and struggles were unimportant and had it's story cut short, but that's just how I feel and I don't want to criticize or de-value all y'alls hard work, I'm glad all that hard work payed off, congrats. Your telling me that the being the GODS chose to protect the mountain not only lost to a warturtle but also lost to a Pokemon they have a all the advantages on, not only that but if the they were there killing countless pokemon for who know how long how n the world were they not level 100? A lot of stuff like this in the series does confuse me but this is a series about breaking the rules so I'm not to surprised.

This entire series is a S tier movie, and there are still 2 episodes left. The perspectives are what make this so emotional and effective, You know squirtle was worng but yet through his eyes charmander just attacked the caterpies to level up and evolve, through caterpies'  eyes it just wanted revenge on charmander for killing his brother. This makes it so there is no one hero or villain. Just like the real world everyone has a reason, This makes the emotions feel so real, you can see where each of the characters come from. Charmander's character development is insane, and now squirtle can see that, Squirtle now sees that caterpie was not the trainer of his dreams, and that he chose to do the things it told him to do. It wasn't "bluey's" fault it was his. That hit me so hard. Cannot wait for the last two episodes, this 8 years were worth it.

A really great episode. This wasn't where I was expecting the series to go, but it is a really interesting turn. I feel like making a prediction (or at least my guess) about what is going to happen in the future episodes.  (Spoiler warning if anyone is reading this before watching the episode)  Wartortle is going to go through another trial concerning his past while he climbs to the mountain summit, perhaps this will be in the form of meeting Whiskers, Caterpie, or Bulbasaur and finding out how things have changed for them since they last saw one another (I would personally bet on it being Bulbasaur if this is the case, as it would force Wartortle to look back on how he did nothing to help another previous friend, while also helping to strengthen his resolve in finding a way to change things, especially since Bulbasaur would likely join him for the remainder of his adventure as his friend).   Once they get to the top of the mountain, the group will have to deal with Missingno and Mewtwo's fight against it. Either because of defeating it, or through something Missingno does, Wartortle will be sent back in time to the point where he could have saved Charmander from Caterpie and this time choose friendship over loyalty. Not sure exactly how it will go down, but I think Squirtle will save Charmander (potentially taking the hit for the fire type in the process, and furthering Charmander's resolve to do things together as a team of friends) and Charmander will take down Caterpie either alone (before tending to Squirtle's injury and saving him if Squirtle did take a life threatening blow), or alongside Squirtle alowing the original trio to continue their adventures like they did before, only with a newfound sense of comrodery and respect for one another and their views.

CHARMANDER, NO!!!!
Okay, I'm about to risk being everybody's worst enemy for leaving this comment, but I honestly want to treat this as an open discussion. I have nothing but respect and admiration for Shipp and the things he creates, and every word of what you're about to read comes from a place of love and compassion. I'm not looking to change hearts and minds here. I only intend to articulate my perspective coming out of this for the first time, and I appreciate anyone who wishes to give it a read.  There's an interesting dynamic presented when you kill off your only active protagonist, as the whole story is gonna stop dead in it's tracks until your passive protagonist(s) physically can't stay passive anymore. Following Charmander's death, there was only ever one way this narrative could possibly play out. Squirtle and Bulbasaur lose Charmander, the only person that _forced_ them into action, they become complacent, stagnating in their prison indefinitely, Caterpie's poor leadership runs the whole forest into the ground, and the whole prison crumbles around them until there's literally no other choice left _but_ to leave. This chain of events is effectively unavoidable given the plot threads that led us here.  I find it disappointing then, not that this is where we took things, but that this episode lays all of this out and has nothing else to say for itself. As a self-contained episode, Charmander's death plays more like empty shock value than anything thought provoking, which is really unfortunate because I don't think it's intentional. We spend more time flaunting his corpse as a trophy than we spend experiencing how his friends were personally impacted by watching their friend die. The most we get to see is what his absence meant for Squirtle's freedom, the trauma it indirectly subjected him to in becoming a mindless soldier, and his attempts to fill the void with replacement friends played for laughs. Maybe some cards were being deliberately played close to the chest, but as a self-contained experience, the way this sequence of events was handled felt a bit shallow to me.  The grand revelation we end with is the passive protagonist determining they must learn to be more active, but the 10 year time jump kind of already spells out for us that this is a problem Squirtle needs to overcome. This effectively results in an episode that feels nonproductive as it's narrative doesn't grow or evolve over time. It just sort of keeps restating the narrative by showing the problem over and over until Squirtle finally figures it out. But that's ultimately the big takeaway from the episode, and I found it's lack of exploration a bit disappointing.  Killing off Charmander is a huge narrative risk, given that so many rudiments of the show were centered around how his actions impacted the people around him, and while I recognize the desire to depict the harshness of reality, where sometimes people's stories just end abruptly, Charmander's death took a lot of the narrative progression with him, and I don't think this episode offered enough substance to make up for the plot threads Charmander once juggled. I can only hope this episode was simply meant to act as a stepping stone to get to the parts of this story Shipp's _actually_ excited to tell, but knowing how much love, dedication, and time Shipp puts into these episodes, it's fair to say we won't be getting any answers for a good while, so I'm bummed like crazy I didn't love everything I saw today.

(Spoilers) There's layers to Squirtle's being broken in the flashback. When Caterpie triggered his rage in the first flashback, Squirtle looks at him and denied his evolution as he calmed down. He wasn't looking at Caterpie; he was looking at the severed head of Charmander worn as a hat. It reminded him his lashing out costed his friend's life, and his fear of losing control and taking responsibility finally broke him into a mindless slave. This is the best episode by far in showing drastic character growth (or regression)!  My current theory of the next episode would be Bluey dueling Arceus to rewind time and preventing Charmander's death, and the finale could be the squad handling the Missingno situation.

This was truly worth the wait!
Wow, the last episode's ending really *was* an epilogue to something grand and tragic. Charmander's story truly ended on that bleak of a note. Squirtle lost his empathy. Bulbasaur never escaped his fate, because he didn't *want* to. And the Caterpie leader just walked away after instigating the end of all life, PokÃ©mon *and* mankind, in Kanto. The characters we've come to know for 9 episodes, except one, are gone. The Starter Squad we've enjoyed for the past 8 years... is over, and we didn't even get to say good-bye to it, because there was no way of knowing that we *had* to. But whatever happened to Mewtwo? Isn't Missingno still a threat, waiting to pop up again any day? I hope they weren't Red Herrings! Don't leave us hanging on those!  On the brighter side of things, though, the evolution was awesome! If our boy, best Starter, has grown *this* much stronger after evolving once, i'd love to see what kind of damage he'd be able to do in his *final* form.  I eagerly await the next installment, where i'm pretty sure Wartortle is going to meet with the gods and defy the laws of nature. Even if he has to Tackle Arceus himself, he's going to give himself another chance at having a team, a circle of friends, a family, or die trying to get it.  With how much Starter Squad episodes have grown in scale by now, i'm expecting Episode 11 (provided nothing happens to cease episode production altogether) to be done and out by the series' 10th anniversary at the earliest.

no way finally
This episode was extremely entertaining, but the story is a little bit okay to me. I like the fact that they made us have high expectations for Charmander when the sad and realistic truth was that there was nothing anybody could have done to stop his death. The Caterpie destruction of the forest was really cool, and I think Squirtle's way of coping with Bulbasaur's separation and Charmander's death by using Turtwig and Chimchar was sweet but sad. In the end, the same thing happened, Turtwig left and Chimchar died. Also, Abomasnow as a reflection of Squirtle being a soldier was creative, and Squirtle's epic god mode was cool. The story is nice, but I am just sad that we are probably never getting more of Charmander, and probably Bulbasaur too. Honestly, I dislike Chimchar, and Turtwig is not nearly as good as Bulbasaur, but it was still fun to see what happened. I expect Mewtwo and the cave he was talking about in that past episode is going to be brought up, but we shall see. Based on what I have seen so far though, I don't think I am going to be much a fan of this, I've never been a fan of time skips and showing much things have changed, it just kind of sucks and lets out a bad vibe. Still fun episode though.
Finally

The fact that squirtle (wartortle) goes through that soul-less stage of fighting a war. Going through war, getting depressed, losing all emotion, these are all factors that are in the terrors of war. After Squirtle fights for a decent amount of time. The 3 flashbacks were my favourite scenes, they give a brief amount of ideology behind Squirtle and the numerous amount of fights he went through. The "Gods" that the Obamasnow speaks of is definitely palkia and dialga adding to the lore aspect. Overall this episode was the most depressing/best one yet.

Really, this is VERY different from the beginning. -Either you just chose to write differently, or- the abscene of turns and fainting spread far beyond that forest. Don't think we didn't notice 'Char kicking so many Bidoofs in a row, or the overall lack of Humans. ...That's why Squirtle was level 98, isn't it? Without rare candies, that's the only way he'd still have room to evolve twice. There was definitely space when fighting (the most epic Abomasnow ever) for both Watortle and Blastoise, but the full evolution's clearly (literally can be seen) being saved for the final two episodes. Speaking of... is there really space for Missigno AND the Gods, or will it join the scrapped plot? Either way, you've made more than enough from your old lighthearted short. Whatever you decide to do, it'll be renowned!  P.S. Oddly respect the concept of not evolving. Sure, it'd give more power, but Blastoise wouldn't be nearly as nimble. Separately, "Do not attempt to talk to the giant tree"... decent line, but was it worth it? Would've been funny if it truth it was the other Snovers huddled together.

This was so damn good! The animation, the story itself, the mix of playful comedy and serious tragedies... This has been cooking for years and I do say the story baked is well done!  As for my personal feelings? I fucking loved it, could understand Squirtle's feelings very well, and can see how this turned after ep.9. I will say that the Catierpie leader really took the phrase: 'You don't know what you have till it's gone.' Very seriously. But it makes sense in a way. She only saw the pros at the end, never realizing that the cons could(and very clearly did) wipe out both the opposing sides with the forest. Only when the fires go out and the ash settled did it finally, absolutely final, that it clicked to her. She was warned, now she has nothing to lose at all.  That is the beauty of this story as we could see that exact thing coming before it did, if you analyze Charmander's story. You could see some of the Pokemon around him change when they meet Charmander and deal with him breaking the rules. That, of it could just be me reaching here.  Also the thing Squirtle fears? I actually don't know, it flew over my head. I watched this repeatedly and can't find the awnser. Not a solid one anyway. If someone could help me, that be a great help!

Man this was awesome
I'm impressed... Of everything. I'd never thought Charmander would die like this. And dying... It's never gonna happen in a Pokemon game, and that's what makes this project so amazing and dark and exciting. Charmander had been learning empathy before he died, and honestly, the star of this project.   This... Took an unexpecting turn. In "Three More Left", Charmander and Bulbasaur were in some mysterious place, ironically it looks like Missingno and there's a Ghastly in it. After the episode 10 preview, Squirtle is probably the only one that survives.   Chimchar and Charmander had a lot in common, both had similar personalities, similar colors, had "char" (meaning "to burn") in their name, died and Squirtle was sad about it. And probably the only reason Squirtle chose to help Chimchar, he failed to help and guide Charmander and hope that he can return the favor. If Caterpie had not trained Squirtle to be completely loyal, on a blind level, to trust him, Squirtle might have prevented this war from happening. The despair of knowing the wrongs and can't do anything about it made a huge impact on him. Normal people might have already given up, but Squirtle turned that to the motivation to do what he believes is right. And that, made me respect Squirtle a lot.   I am very excited for another episode and hoping that Wartortle will become Blastoise! The animation, voice acting, plot, story-telling is all so great and definitely worth the wait. But looks like it will be "Two Episodes Left", I'm sad this series is coming to an end because of how great it was. Honestly I would be totally excited if Shipp can start another amazing project after this. Also, looking forward to Charmander, if possible.   Thank you Shipp and his team for this amazing project! I'm so glad I found this!

This episode hit me hard, but it got me thinking well and good after my nightmare last night. Just like how Wartortle did, the best way to live life is to live it our own way, not by what someone expects or demands from us. I used to live that type of "do as expected of you, or else" life back then, and I've hurt a lot of people because of that. Now? I'll be moving out to my boyfriend AND girlfriend next month, where the four of us (since our girlfriend has a son) can be a whole and complete family together. Plus, my partners have been through similar hardships as I have, so our bonds have only gotten stronger since we got back together from years of our drama and loss. This episode of Starter Squad was a very good reminder of not only keeping my head up high but also to do the best that only I can do. I'm my own person and always have been.  Thanks, Shippidge. Keep up the awesome work, and I'll be happy to wait for as long as it takes for the last two episodes. More importantly, I hope you're having a great time making this series with your pals and cohorts. Toodles! ğŸ’™

Alright, did some googling, pokemon red and blue came out in 1998, and then diamond and pearl, the first gen 4 games with those new starters, came out in 2006, eight years later. THE 2 YEAR WAIT IS FINALLY OVER
That was... A lot. To take in. Charmander's death, the war and seeing how pathetic squirtle was broke me. He treated everything as a everyday adventure. Because that was all he had before he lost it all. Caterpie finally understanding that he's in the wrong was...sudden. And bulbasaur choosing to be food and eating fruits his entire life is messed up to say the least, but it fits him. Also Shippiddge has no mercy on killing characters off whenever he wants like god damn, but that's how real life is, you dont get anime miracles, you die. Doesnt matter if it's sudden, or anti-climatic. Life isnt a movie. It's cruel and horrifying, that's why i dont think charmander's going to be revived. If he did then that ruins the whole point of the episode. And caterpie wasn't killed or anything even after all they've done, is unsatisfying but that's also how real life is, bad guys dont get what they deserve most of the time and it's infuriating. What a crazy episode. Shame we dont get to hear shippiddge's iconic voice anymore. Edit: Guys, get over it. Charmander's dead. Deal with it.

Definitely one of the best episodes yet. It seems time has not been kind to poor old squirtle...  (if you haven't watched this yet, don't read past this line, Spoilers and such)  It seems the death of charmander weighed more heavily on squirtle than I thought, Turtwig was absolutely right about him. That everstone he valued so highly was the perfect representation of his mental state. Squirtle was stuck in the past, he didn't want to move on, he was desperate to re-capture his youth, to bring back the friends, the team he once knew.   Thankfully, it seems he's finally chosen to move on, discarding the everstone and letting go of the past. Upon evolving to a wartortle, it is VERY apparent how much he was holding himself back. If he's that strong as a Wartortle, then as a blastoise, his strength could match or even possibly surpass that of a GOD. I'm looking forward to seeing where this goes next.  On a side note, I'm a little dissapointed that the whole MissingNo/Mewtwo plot line didn't really go anywhere (and was seemingly forgotten). Fortunately, what we got instead was simply amazing. That being said, it would be nice to see that previous plot at least get a reference in this new story. I can understand if you choose not to, and I'll be fine with whatever outcome.

Did you really try to fully reboot this series   Gamers rise let us riot this fucking channel
This was a phenomenal masterpiece of an episode.  I'm going to make a review below because I am this amazed. First and foremost, there will be spoilers from the episode and this is quite lengthy so read in your own interest but I hope I'm not too much of a bore. Here we go:  I just want to give kudos to the way Squirtle's trauma was handled, and shows the conflict between being autonomous and being an agent (essentially being under the control of another person and how that can affect someone. Remember when Red first picked Squirtle at the start of this series? Squirtle saw that as a privilege and was pretty pleased about it at first but the "being ordered around by a trainer" gist began to take a toll on him as he started to feel apathetic and seemingly ruthless under the control of the Caterpie, as he was almost brainwashed and felt like his responsibilities and actions weren't his own; he's just doing as he's told. And of course, due to binding factors that keep one within this agentic state, it is difficult to escape from such control as seen with Squirtle even going against his own moral principles (he's always seemed to have his heart in the right place). Compare this to when he was traveling with Charmander and Bulbasaur. Although he may had not gotten along well with Charmander and has experienced some misfortunes, he felt more free and sympathetic, especially when being around company that will have his back and he can always sort of rely on. You can see how much this meant to Squirtle as Turtwig points out that he's trying to recreate a long-lost memory of some sorts by having a starter trio traveling together, and not even remembering their names. You can see how much Char and Bulb meant to Squirtle, and how the loss of both of them - coupled with being devoid of any emotion or liberty when being under Caterpie's control - had on him (yeah Bulbasaur is most likely still alive but he didn't want to come).   I may be wrong when I say this but I feel like Charmander's rebellious nature had rubbed off on Squirtle a bit when he was out on the mission to get Chimchar back (who sort of embodies Charmander's egocentric spirit). This cue gave Squirtle the realization that he always had a choice and his actions were his own, and this is what the Abomasnow failed to realize. Even if you were ordered to commit heinous acts against your own will, the blood will still come on your hands too unfortunately. Maybe not as much but you're still contributing a cause whether you like it or not, and that's the dark reality. You'll feel regret for an action that you didn't want to do in the first place as it may defy your moral code. There's that limit where you may realize that you could be held accountable for what you are doing soon, and I think this what made Squirtle snap and unleash his defiance not only against the Abomasnow but to his unwillingness to evolve. He wanted to relive the memory that he had with his two other starter buddies and didn't want to change who he was but he came to accept the fact that changes have to be made at a point and things can't go the way they are forever. This is truly what builds him up to be the strong-willed Wartortle that we now recently know and hopefully love.   Things can't stay the same forever and I like how history kind of repeats itself in some sort of way. You had Chimchar (the Charmander embodiment) die eventually and Turtwig (the more sassier Bulbasaur equivalent) not wanting to tag along anymore. Dreams won't always come true and there has to be a point where you take reality into your own hands and realize "Hey, maybe I have to just move on and accept the facts". I personally feel like this is what the episode taught us the most and is truly the greatest highlight of it.  Of course, props to the whole team for such a spectacular episode. The voice acting, overall designs, effects etc. were all amazing in their own ways. I was blown away by the details and I was kept immersed the whole way through.   I can't wait to see where this story heads towards next.

i got goosepumps when i saw the notification
Episode 10 of Starter Squad is finally finished.  Thank you to all those involved and thank you for your extreme patience.  This took me roughly twice as much time to make as I'd anticipated it taking, but in the end it came out pretty dang close to how it looked in my head.  Please enjoy and/or be upset by the video and be sure to Like and Subscribe!  I'm going to write some spoiler-y stuff below now, so make sure you've watched the whole episode before reading the rest of this comment.   SPOILERS    .......     SPOILERS     .....    SPOILERS    ...   Hah!  Didn't expect that, did you!?  DID YOU!?!  I didn't begin this series with the expectation that it would go into Sinnoh, but I made the decision long ago (around Episode 6 in 2015/2016) and have since building up to the Sinnoh Arc for Squirtle in Episodes 7-9.  Episode 10 of Starter Squad was written in late 2019/early 2020 and its production cycle spanned the 2020 global pandemic.  Hats off to everyone that worked on this during a strict quarantine.  Additionally, during the production of this episode, remakes of the Gen 4 Pokemon games were announced.  I'm not sure if this was pure coincidence or simply parallel thinking between me and Nintendo.  I have, after all, been completely indoctrinated by their products, so it only makes sense that my actions would parallel theirs.  The timing felt very strange and nerve-wracking to me when it was announced.  But hopefully this will open up a whole new viewer base, and people will be more likely to find this series as a result.   If you're reading this before Ep11's release, rest assured that I'm going somewhere with this weird plot shift.  I intend for Starter Squad to be a 12 episode series.  There are two episodes left for me to make, and I do not plan to make a second "season".  Please believe me when I say that I have no idea when I'll be able to release the next episode.  I often lose sight of how long things take and often run into unexpected problems.  Additionally, in every single episode thus far, I have attempted to animate something I've never tried before in my life and always step into uncharted territory in order to expand my skill set.  I am going to attempt to make two more episodes and be more efficient with the production process, but I have no idea what that will look like at this time.  I did about 85% of the animation of this episode entirely by myself, and I definitely need to expand my team for the next one.  Feel free to contact me if you're experienced with both character animation and Blender and are interested in working on the series.  If you'd like to support the series and receive regular updates on the next Episode's production, visit Patreon.com/shippiddge. If you enjoy looking at the things I type, you can follow me on Twitter (twitter.com/shippiddge).  Thank you all sincerely for watching.  - Pierce "Shippiddge" Shipp
